column2: Anthea walked straight past the uncomfortable parlourmaid, and the others followed her.
column3: Anthea walked straight past the uncomfortable parlourmaid, and the others followed her.

column2: Mrs Biddle had her back to them, and was smoothing down the carpet with the same boot that had trampled on the hand of Robert.
column3: Mrs Biddle had her back to them, and was smoothing down the carpet with the same boot that had trampled on the hand of Robert.

column2: So that they were all in the room, and Cyril, with great presence of mind, had shut the room door before she saw them.
column3: So that they were all in the room, and Cyril, with great presence of mind, had shut the room door before she saw them.

column2: 'Who is it, Jane?' she asked in a sour voice; and then turning suddenly, she saw who it was.
column3: 'Who is it, Jane?' she asked in a sour voice; and then turning suddenly, she saw who it was.

column2: Once more her face grew violet--a deep, dark violet. 'You wicked daring little things!' she cried, 'how dare you come here? At this time of night, too.
column3: Once more her face grew violet-a deep, dark violet. 'You wicked daring little things!' she cried, 'how dare you come here? At this time of night, too.

column2: Be off, or I'll send for the police.'
column3: Be off, or I'll send for the police.'

column2: 'Don't be angry,' said Anthea, soothingly, 'we only wanted to ask you to let us have the carpet.
column3: 'Don't be angry,' said Anthea, soothingly, 'we only wanted to ask you to let us have the carpet.

column2: We have quite twelve shillings between us, and--'
column3: We have quite twelve shillings between us, and-'

column2: 'How DARE you?' cried Mrs Biddle, and her voice shook with angriness.
column3: 'How DARE you?' cried Mrs Biddle, and her voice shook with angriness.

column2: 'You do look horrid,' said Jane suddenly.
column3: 'You do look horrid,' said Jane suddenly.

column2: Mrs Biddle actually stamped that booted foot of hers.
column3: Mrs Biddle actually stamped that booted foot of hers.

column2: 'You rude, barefaced child!' she said.
column3: 'You rude, barefaced child!' she said.

column2: Anthea almost shook Jane; but Jane pushed forward in spite of her.
column3: Anthea almost shook Jane; but Jane pushed forward in spite of her.

column2: 'It really IS our nursery carpet,' she said, 'you ask ANY ONE if it isn't.'
column3: 'It really IS our nursery carpet,' she said, 'you ask ANY ONE if it isn't.'

column2: 'Let's wish ourselves home,' said Cyril in a whisper.
column3: 'Let's wish ourselves home,' said Cyril in a whisper.

column2: 'No go,' Robert whispered back, 'she'd be there too, and raving mad as likely as not.
column3: 'No go,' Robert whispered back, 'she'd be there too, and raving mad as likely as not.

column2: Horrid thing, I hate her!'
column3: Horrid thing, I hate her!'

column2: 'I wish Mrs Biddle was in an angelic good temper,' cried Anthea, suddenly.
column3: 'I wish Mrs Biddle was in an angelic good temper,' cried Anthea, suddenly.

column2: 'It's worth trying,' she said to herself.
column3: 'It's worth trying,' she said to herself.

column2: Mrs Biddle's face grew from purple to violet, and from violet to mauve, and from mauve to pink.
column3: Mrs Biddle's face grew from purple to violet, and from violet to mauve, and from mauve to pink.

column2: Then she smiled quite a jolly smile.
column3: Then she smiled quite a jolly smile.

column2: 'Why, so I am!' she said, 'what a funny idea!
column3: 'Why, so I am!' she said, 'what a funny idea!

column2: Why shouldn't I be in a good temper, my dears.'
column3: Why shouldn't I be in a good temper, my dears.'

column2: Once more the carpet had done its work, and not on Mrs Biddle alone.
column3: Once more the carpet had done its work, and not on Mrs Biddle alone.

column2: The children felt suddenly good and happy.
column3: The children felt suddenly good and happy.

column2: 'You're a jolly good sort,' said Cyril. 'I see that now.
column3: 'You're a jolly good sort,' said Cyril. 'I see that now.

column2: I'm sorry we vexed you at the bazaar to-day.'
column3: I'm sorry we vexed you at the bazaar to day.'

column2: 'Not another word,' said the changed Mrs Biddle.
column3: 'Not another word,' said the changed Mrs Biddle.

column2: 'Of course you shall have the carpet, my dears, if you've taken such a fancy to it.
column3: 'Of course you shall have the carpet, my dears, if you've taken such a fancy to it.

column2: No, no; I won't have more than the ten shillings I paid.'
column3: No, no; I won't have more than the ten shillings I paid.'

column2: 'It does seem hard to ask you for it after you bought it at the bazaar,' said Anthea; 'but it really IS our nursery carpet.
column3: 'It does seem hard to ask you for it after you bought it at the bazaar,' said Anthea; 'but it really IS our nursery carpet.

column2: It got to the bazaar by mistake, with some other things.'
column3: It got to the bazaar by mistake, with some other things.'

column2: 'Did it really, now?
column3: 'Did it really, now?

column2: How vexing!' said Mrs Biddle, kindly.
column3: How vexing!' said Mrs Biddle, kindly.

column2: 'Well, my dears, I can very well give the extra ten shillings; so you take your carpet and we'll say no more about it.
column3: 'Well, my dears, I can very well give the extra ten shillings; so you take your carpet and we'll say no more about it.

column2: Have a piece of cake before you go!
column3: Have a piece of cake before you go!

column2: I'm so sorry I stepped on your hand, my boy.
column3: I'm so sorry I stepped on your hand, my boy.

column2: Is it all right now?'
column3: Is it all right now?'

column2: 'Yes, thank you,' said Robert.
column3: 'Yes, thank you,' said Robert.

column2: 'I say, you ARE good.'
column3: 'I say, you ARE good.'

column2: 'Not at all,' said Mrs Biddle, heartily.
column3: 'Not at all,' said Mrs Biddle, heartily.

column2: 'I'm delighted to be able to give any little pleasure to you dear children.'
column3: 'I'm delighted to be able to give any little pleasure to you dear children.'

column2: And she helped them to roll up the carpet, and the boys carried it away between them.
column3: And she helped them to roll up the carpet, and the boys carried it away between them.

column2: 'You ARE a dear,' said Anthea, and she and Mrs Biddle kissed each other heartily.
column3: 'You ARE a dear,' said Anthea, and she and Mrs Biddle kissed each other heartily.

column2: 'WELL!' said Cyril as they went along the street.
column3: 'WELL!' said Cyril as they went along the street.

column2: 'Yes,' said Robert, 'and the odd part is that you feel just as if it was REAL--her being so jolly, I mean--and not only the carpet making her nice.'
column3: 'Yes,' said Robert, 'and the odd part is that you feel just as if it was REAL-her being so jolly, I mean-and not only the carpet making her nice.'

column2: 'Perhaps it IS real,' said Anthea, 'only it was covered up with crossness and tiredness and things, and the carpet took them away.'
column3: 'Perhaps it IS real,' said Anthea, 'only it was covered up with crossness and tiredness and things, and the carpet took them away.'

column2: 'I hope it'll keep them away,' said Jane; 'she isn't ugly at all when she laughs.'
column3: 'I hope it'll keep them away,' said Jane; 'she isn't ugly at all when she laughs.'

column2: The carpet has done many wonders in its day; but the case of Mrs Biddle is, I think, the most wonderful.
column3: The carpet has done many wonders in its day; but the case of Mrs Biddle is, I think, the most wonderful.

column2: For from that day she was never anything like so disagreeable as she was before, and she sent a lovely silver tea-pot and a kind letter to Miss Peasmarsh when the pretty lady married the nice curate; just after Easter it was, and they went to Italy for their honeymoon.
column3: For from that day she was never anything like so disagreeable as she was before, and she sent a lovely silver tea pot and a kind letter to Miss Peasmarsh when the pretty lady married the nice curate; just after Easter it was, and they went to Italy for their honeymoon.
